title: 11 Notable New Releases Over the Next Two Weeks
text:
To Do: September 18-October 2 Our biweekly guide on what to see, hear, watch, and read. Photo: Courtesy of the networks (Marling, Hader); Patrick McMullan (Rodriguez)

TV

1. Watch American Horror Story: 1984

There’s a killer on the loose, obviously.

The ninth (!) season of American Horror Story takes on the slasher flicks of the ’80s as it follows a group of aerobics instructors who start working at a summer camp famous for its massacres. The Friday the 13th homage stars several Ryan Murphy Universe regulars, including Emma Roberts and Billie Lourd. —Jen Chaney

FX, September 18.

Books

2. Read The Water Dancer

Conversations on race.

Ta-Nehisi Coates transformed how we talk about racial justice with his call for reparations. His first novel, the magic-realist slave-escape narrative The Water Dancer, is out September 24. —Boris Kachka

One World, September 24.

TV

3. Watch The Good Place

It’s the last season? Are you forkin’ kidding me?

The existential comedy returns for its fourth and final season, which will involve one last attempt to prove humans are capable of changing for the better and, presumably, one more opportunity for Kristen Bell’s Eleanor to say “shrampy.” —J.C.

NBC, September 26.

Movies

4. See Say Amen, Somebody

Roger Ebert called it “joyful.”

Many of the pioneers of black gospel music were still holding on — and shouting — when George T. Nierenberg shot the interviews for his smashing 1982 documentary, now restored and primed for a national theatrical rerelease at a time when we need our minds and souls both soothed and buoyed. Thomas A. Dorsey (who’s said to have merged the sacred and the profane — i.e., jazz — to create the gospel gene), Mother Willie Mae Ford Smith, and the Barrett Sisters (who are still two-thirds around) are natural talkers but supernatural performers. —David Edelstein

In theaters; Film Society of Lincoln Center, through September 26.

TV

5. Watch mixed-ish

There is now, officially, an “-ish” universe.

Young Bow (Arica Himmel) is the central focus of this new ABC sitcom, which flashes back to follow Tracee Ellis Ross’s black-ish character during her coming-of-age years in the ’80s as the daughter of an interracial marriage who must adjust to suburbia after living on a commune. —J.C.

ABC, September 24.

Pop Music

6. Listen to Jaime

A powerful record.

Alabama Shakes’ Brittany Howard prepares a first solo album named for Howard’s older sister, who lost her battle with cancer when the singer was young. The new set is a deeper exploration of the gobsmacking vocals and guitar playing that are Howard’s trademarks. —Craig Jenkins

ATO, September 20.

TV

7. Watch Savage x Fenty Show

Rihanna’s lingerie fashion show.

Rihanna is coming for Victoria’s Secret’s turf. Her second annual Savage x Fenty lingerie runway show took place during Fashion Week, but you can see it here a week later. Last season was so exciting one pregnant model went into labor. This year, it’s a concert with Migos performing and artists like Normani walking the show.

Amazon Prime Video, September 20.

TV

8. Watch Evil

A crime show with a dollop of Ghost Hunters.

Robert and Michelle King, creators of The Good Wife and The Good Fight, are behind this new series about an expert in criminal psychology (Katja Herbers), a priest-in-training (Mike Colter of Luke Cage), and a skeptical contractor (Aasif Mandvi) who investigate supernatural phenomena. The pilot is off-kilter, creepy, and worth watching. —J.C.

CBS, September 26.

Pop Music

9. Listen to Jesus Is King

Yeezy season approaching.

If you’ve been tracking Kanye West’s recent Sunday Service performances, at which the rapper and producer corrals a chorus of singers for a lively mix of gospel songs, hip-hop and R&B covers, and new renditions of his own hits, you should keep an eye out for his forthcoming solo album, Jesus Is King, a purer synthesis of the blend of rap and liturgical music West has been onto since “Jesus Walks.” —C.J.

G.O.O.D. Music, September 27.

TV

10. Watch Transparent Musicale Finale

Farewell, Pfeffermans.

After allegations of inappropriate behavior by Transparent star Jeffrey Tambor, the Amazon series about the Pfefferman family is going out in song with a two-hour movie musical that centers on the funeral for Maura, the character Tambor played. —J.C.

Amazon, September 27.

TV

11. Watch Saturday Night Live

We’ll miss you, Leslie.

When we all fall asleep, where do we go? Look, Billie Eilish, I don’t know, but I do know that when we aren’t asleep on Saturday nights, we watch SNL.

This season’s premiere will be hosted by Woody Harrelson, who’s joined by musical guest … Billie Eilish. —J.C.

NBC, September 28.

*A version of this article appears in the September 16, 2019, issue of New York Magazine. Subscribe Now!
description: Vulture editors choose the best new releases in culture, including American Horror Story: 1984, Ta-Nehisi Coates’s The Water Dancer, The Good Place, mixed-ish, Savage x Fenty Show on Amazon, Kanye West’s Jesus Is King, Saturday Night Live, and more.
